name: Materiales Vallejo
caption: Designing and building a material store’s first website

hero.alt: Materiales Vallejo Case Study: Designing and building a material store's first website.

content.text: Materiales Vallejo is a small building material store in Matamoros, Mexico selling cement, steel rebars, and other building materials to local clients. The business needed a website to engage with new clients and to serve as a tool to expedite their hiring process.
Note: The official business website is in Spanish so I made an English site to use as reference for this case study.

Materiales Vallejo’s revenue comes from sales to local material stores, hardware stores, construction firms and individuals. Most clients are long-term, loyal clients and have a close relationship with the business. Clients are used to negotiate product pricing and payment terms. As a consequence, phone and in-person interactions are preferred to facilitate negotiation. Clients call the business at least once a week to inquire about product availability and establish new orders.

Materiales Vallejo uses manual processes for daily management tasks. It doesn’t count with an up-to-date inventory system and most of its sales transactions are made with cash. When there’s an available job, the business purchases newspaper and radio ads with a job description and application instructions. Interested applicants are asked to purchase a job application form at a local office supply store and deliver the application in person or email a scanned copy.

The core user profile is based on Materiales Vallejo’s client profile. Most clients are familiar with building material use and terminology and prefer to engage with the business on the phone. Core users are construction firm secretaries and small business owners hunting for the cheapest prices across town. Core users will need to know about the business, what it offers, and how to get in touch with the business.

Secondary users are potential job applicants that will find out about the available job through a newspaper or radio ad. Instead of sending applicants to purchase an application form, the ad will provide a link to the job detail page where potential new hires will find out more about the job and fill out and submit an application form.

The website was designed to provide a fast but complete run through of the business. The site has a landing page, about page, and dynamic careers pages. The landing page was designed primarily for core users, and provides all the information they need for a quick experience. The landing page was designed for fast consumption to minimize search time and maximize the probability of turning the visit into an engagement.

The navigation menu is fixed and has a contact button that displays the available form of contact at the time of visit. If the store is open, the button invites users to call the store. If the business is away for lunch or closed, the button invites users to send an email.

media.alt: Dynamic desktop navigation menus and dynamic mobile contact buttons.
media.caption: Dynamic desktop and mobile contact buttons.

content.text: The landing page's hero section has a dark background to focus the user's attention on the section's content, which briefly describes who the business is and what it does. The section has two buttons that link to the product and service sections to provide fast links to important sections of the page.

A carousel was designed to provide a quick way of navigating through the available products. Products were grouped by category for fast product navigation and categories were ordered by popularity. On desktops, users can navigate the carousel with the navigation arrows. On mobiles and tablets, users can scroll through the carousel to navigate through the available products.

media.alt: Desktop product carousel with navigation arrows
media.caption: Desktop product carousel with navigation arrows

content.text: Product cards were designed to inform users about product availability. Tapping the card displays details about sale unit and available measurements. Product cards don’t display prices to increase the probability of the user engaging with the business.

media.alt: Default and active product card states
media.caption: Default and active product card states

content.text: The contact section displays dynamic content that updates based on the store’s current status. If the business is open, the section’s description invites users to call the business and the store number is highlighted and calls the store. If the business is out for lunch or closed, the section’s description informs the user of the store’s status and the email is highlighted and opens the user’s email client.

media.alt: Mobile contact sections—open out for lunch, and closed states
media.caption: Mobile contact sections: open, out for lunch, and closed states

content.text: When there’s an available job the index and about pages display a job banner above the footer to avoid interrupting the core user’s experience. A careers page is created and lists the available jobs. Each job has a job detail page that displays a brief job description and links to a job application form.

media.alt: Mobile job banner, job detail, and application form
media.caption: Mobile job banner, job detail, and application form

content.text: Materiales Vallejo’s website was published on December 2016 and is tracking user data to provide better insight into user engagement and website use. At the moment, the business is not interested in investing time in ad words campaigns, so it will take some time to acquire a decent amount of user data. Nonetheless, I will be monitoring the site’s usage and working on cross-browser compatibility bugs in the coming weeks.

On another note, through this project I realized there is a need for business automation tools for small businesses in Mexico. There are so many areas where technology could make the lives of entrepreneurs much easier—payment processing, inventory management systems, client management systems, invoicing and PoS systems. I would love to tackle one of these problems in the near future.

The project was a great learning experience and I had a lot of fun running through the full design and development process. When the project started I had prior experience with website builders, a limited understanding of HTML/CSS, and was working on another web project. Throughout the project I faced multiple challenges and made innumerable mistakes on a number of different areas—communication, process, efficiency, design, and development. Through the challenges, mistakes and small successes, I was able to become aware of several principles / ideas—

block.title: Building Tools
block.description: The value of a business website comes from solving real business problems. Business web design is about building usable tools, not useless trophies.

block.title: Communication
block.description: Clear communication is at the core of good design and one of the biggest challenges a designer faces.

block.title: External Factors
block.description: The ideal design solution may not be the right solution due to long-time business habits, technical limitations, and personal and cultural factors.

block.title: Iteration
block.description: Design is not a one-time thing. It's a continuous, long-term process. It's about building, analyzing, and rebuilding with a clear goal.
